Text: Those who trust in the LORD are like Mount Zion, which cannot be moved, but abides forever.
Context: This verse conveys the steadfastness and security of those who trust in God, analogous to Mount Zion's permanence.

Text: As the mountains surround Jerusalem, so the LORD surrounds His people both now and forevermore.
Context: The verse provides comfort, depicting God's protection of His people like the mountains that surround Jerusalem.

Text: The scepter of the wicked will not remain over the land allotted to the righteous, lest the righteous stretch forth their hands to do wrong.
Context: This verse expresses a temporary concern about wicked rulers, but it's also a promise that their rule will not last, preventing the righteous from being tempted to sin.

Text: Do good, O LORD, to those who are good, and to the upright in heart.
Context: This is a prayer asking God to bless the good and upright, implying a means of encouraging moral behavior.

Text: But those who turn to crooked ways the LORD will banish with the evildoers. Peace be upon Israel.
Context: This verse serves as a warning against turning to evil. It contrasts the fate of the wicked with a blessing of peace for Israel.
